questions.text: A 30-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 42 weeks' gestation is admitted to the hospital in active labor. Pregnancy has been complicated by gestational diabetes, for which she has been receiving insulin injections. Her first child was delivered by lower segment transverse cesarean section because of a nonreassuring fetal heart rate. Pulse is 90/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 135/80 mm Hg. The fetal heart rate tracing shows a baseline heart rate of 145/min and moderate variation with frequent accelerations and occasional early decelerations. She undergoes an elective repeat lower segment transverse cesarean section with complete removal of the placenta. Shortly after the operation, she starts having heavy uterine bleeding with passage of clots. Examination shows a soft uterus on palpation. Her bleeding continues despite fundal massage and the use of packing, oxytocin, misoprostol, and carboprost. Her pulse rate is now 120/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 90/70 mm Hg. Her hemoglobin is 8 g/dL, hematocrit is 24%, platelet count is 120,000 mm3, prothrombin time is 11 seconds, and partial thromboplastin time is 30 seconds. Mass transfusion protocol is activated and a B-Lynch uterine compression suture is placed to control her bleeding. Which of the following is the most likely cause of her postpartum complication?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Uterine atony usually manifests with an enlarged, soft, non-contracted uterus and significant vaginal bleeding after delivery due to insufficient myometrial blood vessel constriction. In uterine atony, bimanual uterine massage and uterotonic agents (oxytocin, misoprostol, carboprost) should be used to promote uterine contraction and tranexamic acid may be indicated to stop fibrinolysis. If the uterus remains soft and bleeding persists, a B-Lynch uterine compression suture can be placed to control bleeding. PPH is an emergency, as it is the number one cause of maternal mortality worldwide.

B) INCORRECT:

Uterine inversion is a rare cause of postpartum hemorrhage and usually occurs in vaginal delivery involving an attached placenta. On vaginal examination, the endometrium is visible as a red bulging mass.

C) INCORRECT:

Although PPH may rarely be the first manifestation of placenta accreta, this condition is associated with the delivery of an incomplete placenta, unlike the placenta in this patient. Placenta accreta is usually diagnosed prior to delivery on ultrasound.

D) INCORRECT:

Hemorrhage can occur from tearing along the lateral aspect of the initial uterine incision, either spontaneously or during delivery of the fetus. However, this type of hemorrhage is usually detected before closing the abdomen. Furthermore, in this case, the uterus would be contracted and firm.

E) INCORRECT:

Uterine rupture can cause postpartum hemorrhage. However, this condition more commonly occurs intrapartum in women with a prior vertical (not transverse) hysterotomy who attempt a vaginal delivery. This patient's soft, enlarged uterus post-cesarean section suggests a most more common etiology of postpartum hemorrhage.

F) INCORRECT:

Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) can cause postpartum hemorrhage due to consumption of clotting factors. However, this patient has a normal PT and PTT, which is not consistent with DIC.
questions.hint: This complication is the most common cause of postpartum hemorrhage (PPH). Overdistention of the uterus (e.g., multiparity, post-term pregnancy) is a risk factor for this condition.

questions.text:
A 27-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 2, at 41 weeks' gestation is admitted to the hospital in active labor. Her pregnancy has been uncomplicated. Her first two children were delivered by vaginal birth. She has a history of asthma. Current medications include iron and vitamin supplements. After a prolonged labor, she undergoes vaginal delivery. Shortly afterward, she begins to have heavy vaginal bleeding with clots. Her temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 130/72 mm Hg. Examination shows a soft, enlarged, and boggy uterus on palpation. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
10.8 g/dL


Hematocrit
32.3%


Leukocyte count
9,000/mm3



Platelet count
140,000/mm3



Prothrombin time
14 seconds


Partial thromboplastin time
38 seconds


Her bleeding continues despite bimanual uterine massage and administration of oxytocin. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hysterectomy is the last resort for the treatment of uterine atony and should only be performed in women unresponsive to medical therapy and uterine tamponade.

B) INCORRECT:

Uterine artery ligation can be performed in stable patients with uterine atony who are unresponsive to conservative interventions and want to avoid hysterectomy. Transcatheter arterial embolization is preferred over direct uterine artery ligation to avoid laparotomy. Regardless, another procedure should be considered initially.

C) INCORRECT:

Dilation and curettage are performed in patients with PPH caused by retained products of conception (RPOC), such as placental fragments or fetal membranes if manual removal has been unsuccessful. This patient presents with a nontender uterus on physical examination and has no fever, neither of which is consistent with RPOC. Uterine atony requires a different management approach.
Image Description:

A gynecological procedure in which the cervix is widened using dilators of increasing diameters (left image) in order to allow insertion of a curette into the uterus for therapeutic or diagnostic tissue removal (right image).

D) INCORRECT:

Uterotonic drugs such as carboprost tromethamine can be administered if bleeding persists after initial first-line pharmacological therapy (e.g., oxytocin). However, carboprost tromethamine is contraindicated in patients with asthma. Other uterotonic drugs that could be used for this patient include methylergonovine and misoprostol.

E) INCORRECT:

A uterine tamponade (e.g., with a balloon or pack) is indicated if bleeding persists despite medical therapy. Uterine tamponade decreases bleeding and provides time to prepare for interventional or surgical options, if necessary. Another procedure should be considered initially.

F) INCORRECT:

Transfusion of blood components may become necessary in PPH with excessive blood loss, in hemodynamically unstable patients, and/or patients with suspected DIC. This patient has stable vital signs and only mild thrombocytopenia and is not at a transfusion Hb threshold (Hb ≤ 6 g/dL independent of clinical findings or Hb < 7–8 g/dL in symptomatic patients).

G) CORRECT:

Uterine atony is the most common cause of PPH and can be managed with bimanual uterine massage in conjunction with prompt administration of the uterine stimulant (uterotonic) oxytocin, followed by additional uterotonic agents (e.g., intramuscular methylergonovine, sublingual or intracavitary misoprostol) and tranexamic acid (TXA). TXA should be given as soon as possible after bleeding onset to stop fibrinolysis and reduce the likelihood of mortality. Surgical interventions (e.g., hysterectomy) may be necessary if conservative therapy has no effect within 30 minutes.

Uterine atony is associated with multiparity, fetal macrosomia, and other conditions that distend the uterus and make myometrial contraction less effective after delivery.
Image Description:

1. One hand is carefully inserted into the anterior vaginal fornix.
2. The inside hand is clenched into a fist while the other hand is placed on the patient's lower abdomen over the uterine fundus.
3. The uterus is compressed and massaged between the two hands until it contracts.
questions.hint: Postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) with a soft, boggy uterus on examination is suggestive of uterine atony.

questions.text:
The response options for the next 2 items are the same. Select one answer for each item in the set.
For each patient with vaginal bleeding, select the most likely diagnosis.
A 37-year-old woman, gravida 4, para 3, at 35 weeks' gestation is admitted to the hospital in active labor. She has had no prenatal care. Two years ago, she delivered her 3rd child by lower segment transverse cesarean section. The patient appears in acute distress. Her pulse is 98/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg. The abdomen is nontender and contractions are felt. The fetus is in a cephalic presentation. The fetal heart rate is reactive with no decelerations. One hour following vaginal delivery, the placenta is not delivered. Manual separation of the placenta leads to profuse vaginal bleeding. A tender uterine fundus is palpated at the level of the umbilicus.
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Uterine atony is the most common cause of postpartum hemorrhage and occurs when the uterus fails to fully contract and compress the uteroplacental vasculature after placental delivery. Patients with a history of multiple pregnancies are at increased risk. However, patients would present with a soft, enlarged, and ascending uterus. This patient has a tender uterus and developed bleeding following attempted manual separation of the placenta.

B) INCORRECT:

Vasa previa causes antepartum, not postpartum hemorrhage.

C) INCORRECT:

Patients with a history of previous cesarean births are particularly prone to uterine rupture due to scarring. Uterine rupture is characterized by sudden onset vaginal bleeding during labor, associated with severe abdominal pain, maternal hemodynamic instability, and fetal distress, none of which are present here. This patient developed bleeding one hour after vaginal delivery following attempted manual separation of the placenta.

D) INCORRECT:

This patient has already delivered the fetus and is no longer in labor.

E) INCORRECT:

Placenta previa causes antepartum, not postpartum hemorrhage.
Image Description:

Schematic frontal section of the uterus (above) and speculum examination with view of the external cervical os (below). Placenta previa is classified based on how much of the cervical os is covered by the placenta.

Low-lying placenta: The lower edge of the placenta is ≤ 2 cm from the internal cervical os.
Marginal placenta previa: The placenta reaches the internal cervical os.
Partial placenta previa: The placenta partially covers the internal cervical os.
Complete previa (total previa): The placenta completely covers the internal cervical os.

F) CORRECT:

Placenta accreta occurs when the placenta is directly adherent to the myometrium instead of the decidua basalis but does not invade or penetrate the myometrium (i.e., placenta increta). The most important risk factor is placenta previa after previous cesarean birth(s). During the prenatal period, patients are often asymptomatic. Diagnosis is generally made via routine prenatal ultrasound (which typically shows thinning of the uterine myometrial wall and irregularly shaped placental lacunae) and Doppler ultrasonography (which typically shows turbulent uterine blood flow and increased myometrial vascularity). Management involves planned surgical delivery with possible hysterectomy to minimize postpartum hemorrhage. In the uncommon event that a placenta accreta is first diagnosed after vaginal delivery, as in this patient, emergency laparotomy is indicated to control the bleeding.
Image Description:

Placental attachment disorders are classified according to the depth of implantation of the trophoblast in the uterine wall:

– Left: Normal placentation
– Placenta accreta: chorionic villi attach to the myometrium rather than the decidua basalis (but do not invade or penetrate the myometrium)
– Placenta increta: chorionic villi invade or penetrate into the myometrium
– Placenta percreta: chorionic villi penetrate the myometrium, penetrate the serosa, and, in some cases, adjacent organs/structures

G) INCORRECT:

Placental abruption causes antepartum, not postpartum hemorrhage.
questions.hint: Delayed placental separation and profuse postpartum hemorrhage following manual placental separation are characteristic features of this patient's condition.

questions.text:
For each patient with vaginal bleeding, select the most likely diagnosis.
A 36-year-old woman, gravida 4, para 3, at 35 weeks' gestation is brought to the emergency department for the evaluation of a sudden, painless, bright red vaginal bleeding for the last hour. She has had no prenatal care. Her third child was delivered by lower segment transverse cesarean section because of a preterm breech presentation; her first two children were delivered vaginally. The patient's pulse is 100/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 105/70 mm Hg. Examination shows a soft, nontender abdomen; no contractions are felt. There is blood on the vulva, the introitus, and on the medial aspect of both thighs. The fetus is in a cephalic presentation. The fetal heart rate is 140/min. One hour later, the bleeding stops.
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Uterine atony causes postpartum, not antepartum hemorrhage!

B) INCORRECT:

Ruptured vasa previa also manifest with a sudden onset of painless bleeding in the third trimester, as in this patient. However, rupture of the vasa previa occurs after rupture of membranes (as the vasa previa are located in the membranes). Since rupture of membranes was not yet observed in this patient, ruptured vasa previa can be ruled out.

C) INCORRECT:

Uterine rupture also manifests with a sudden onset of bleeding in the third trimester, but the condition is characterized by severe abdominal pain and uterine tenderness, maternal hemodynamic instability, and fetal distress.

D) INCORRECT:

A small amount of vaginal bleeding can occur in early labor and is named bloody show. However, the latent phase of labor would be notable for mild contractions. The intensity of the patient's bleeding in this case also indicates another diagnosis.

E) CORRECT:

Placenta previa typically affects women > 35 years old with a history of curettage or, as in this case, cesarean delivery. Like many of the most important differential diagnoses of antepartum hemorrhage, it is characterized by the sudden onset of vaginal bleeding. But contrary to other causes of antepartum bleeding (e.g., placental abruption or uterine rupture), bleeding is painless and often stops spontaneously after 1 or 2 hours. Other differentiating factors are a nontender uterus and the lack of fetal distress in placenta previa.
Image Description:

Schematic frontal section of the uterus (above) and speculum examination with view of the external cervical os (below). Placenta previa is classified based on how much of the cervical os is covered by the placenta.

Low-lying placenta: The lower edge of the placenta is ≤ 2 cm from the internal cervical os.
Marginal placenta previa: The placenta reaches the internal cervical os.
Partial placenta previa: The placenta partially covers the internal cervical os.
Complete previa (total previa): The placenta completely covers the internal cervical os.

F) INCORRECT:

Placenta accreta causes postpartum, not antepartum hemorrhage!

G) INCORRECT:

Abruptio placentae also manifests with a sudden onset of bleeding in the third trimester, but the condition is characterized by mild to moderate abdominal pain, uterine tenderness, and continuous, dark, vaginal bleeding.
questions.hint: It's important to note that the antepartum bleeding in this patient is painless, which rules out several differentials! The remaining differentials can often be differentiated based on the stage of the pregnancy.

questions.text: Forty-five minutes after the spontaneous delivery of a male newborn at 39 weeks' gestation, a 27-year-old primigravid woman reports of worsening abdominal pain and dizziness. The patient was admitted to the hospital 5 hours prior because of spontaneous rupture of membranes. During labor, she experienced a brief episode of inadequate contractions which resolved following administration of IV oxytocin. The placenta was extracted manually after multiple attempts of controlled cord traction and fundal pressure. The patient has no history of serious illness except for occasional nosebleeds. The pregnancy was uncomplicated. Her pulse is 110/min and blood pressure is 85/50 mmHg. There is brisk vaginal bleeding from a round mass protruding from the vagina. The fundus is not palpable on abdominal examination. Which of the following is the most likely cause of bleeding in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While a coagulation disorder (e.g., hemophilia) may also cause postpartum hemorrhage, this patient lacks a personal or family history of bleeding and easy bruising, except for occasional nosebleeds. A protruding mass from the vagina and a nonpalpable fundus suggest a different bleeding cause.

B) INCORRECT:

Persistent vaginal bleeding after delivery should prompt consideration of uterine rupture. However, typically, uterine rupture becomes apparent before delivery with a sudden onset of abdominal pain accompanied by fetal heart rate abnormalities and maternal hemodynamic instability, none of which was present in this patient. A protruding mass from the vagina and a nonpalpable fundus suggest a different diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

While retained placental products are a common cause of postpartum hemorrhage, the placenta has been fully extracted in this patient. The protruding mass from the vagina and the nonpalpable fundus suggest a different cause of bleeding.

D) INCORRECT:

While uterine atony is the most common cause of postpartum hemorrhage, it usually presents with a soft, boggy uterus palpable above the umbilicus on examination. In this patient, no fundus is palpable in the usual location on physical examination. Uterine atony is also more common in multiparous women.

E) CORRECT:

The findings suggest uterine inversion, a rare complication of vaginal birth, and an obstetric emergency that can lead to hemorrhagic shock and maternal death. Risk factors include cord traction (Brandt-Andrews maneuver) and fundal pressure (Crede maneuver) during the third stage of labor and difficulties in removing the placenta, as was the case in this patient. Oxytocin should be discontinued and crystalloids and blood products administered as needed. If the uterus cannot be repositioned manually even after administration of a uterine relaxant (e.g., nitroglycerine), surgical repair becomes necessary.
Image Description:

37 year old women, gravida 4 para 4 who presented in ER right after the birth of her child. She was in pain but did not have active bleeding. The uterus is inverted and prolapsed completely through the vagina and vulva. The insertion site of the placenta (which is not attached anymore) can still be seen as a round, darker part compared to the lighter myometrium.

F) INCORRECT:

A laceration of the cervix may occur during delivery and cause postpartum hemorrhage. However, the protruding mass from the vagina and the nonpalpable fundus suggest a different diagnosis. Once the protruding mass in the vagina is removed in this patient, the entire birth canal should be inspected for significant lacerations that may require repair.
questions.hint: This patient presents with brisk postpartum hemorrhage, lower abdominal pain, a round mass protruding from the vagina, and no fundus (top of the uterus) in place after vaginal delivery. This condition is an obstetric emergency.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 2, delivers twins via an uncomplicated vaginal delivery. The patient received regular prenatal care. Pregnancy was uncomplicated. Shortly after complete delivery of both placentas, there is profuse vaginal bleeding. Postpartum blood loss is estimated to be 1150 mL. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows an enlarged, soft uterus. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Methylergometrine is a uterotonic agent that can be used in cases of PPH secondary to uterine atony. However, methylergometrine is a second-line agent that is used after, or in combination with, first-line interventions. An alternative intervention would be a more appropriate next step in management for this patient. Note that this drug is contraindicated in patients with hypertension or preeclampsia because it can cause severe increases in blood pressure.

B) INCORRECT:

Hysterectomy is the definitive treatment for women with severe and refractory PPH. However, emergency hysterectomy is a last-resort treatment option in hemodynamically unstable patients that do not respond to conservative management. This patient should first undergo a different intervention.

C) INCORRECT:

Uterine artery embolization can be used as a fertility-sparing procedure in patients with slow, hemodynamically stable, yet persistent PPH. Uterine artery embolization is an appropriate treatment option in patients that do not respond to conservative management; however, this patient should first undergo a different intervention.

D) INCORRECT:

Prostaglandins such as misoprostol and carboprost are uterotonic agents that can be used as second-line agents in the management of uterine atony. These drugs have potentially severe side effects (e.g., hypertension, fever, bronchospasm) and should therefore only be used after other interventions have failed to adequately control the bleeding.

E) INCORRECT:

Curettage with suctioning is a treatment modality that can be used for PPH secondary to retained placental tissue. Risk factors for placental retention include prior uterine surgery, uterine fibroids, and preterm delivery. This patient's presentation is consistent with uterine atony, which is not treated by curettage with suctioning.

F) INCORRECT:

Tranexamic acid is an antifibrinolytic agent that acts to prevent plasmin-mediated breakdown of fibrin and can be used to treat excessive bleeding. Although tranexamic acid has been shown to reduce mortality and blood loss from obstetric hemorrhage, it is not the intervention of choice. However, it should be administered immediately if initial interventions fail to adequately control bleeding since delayed administration can decrease its efficacy.

G) CORRECT:

Uterine atony is the most common cause of PPH, accounting for 70–80% of all cases. Initial management involves bimanual uterine massage to induce uterine contraction and the constriction of blood vessels. In addition, patients should receive intravenous fluid resuscitation with crystalloid fluids and an increase in oxytocin infusion to induce uterine contractions. Oxytocin should be routinely administered to all women in the third stage of labor to reduce the risk of developing PPH.

Risk factors for uterine atony include multiparity leading to uterine overdistention (as seen in this patient), prolonged labor, induction of labor, and chorioamnionitis.
Image Description:

1. One hand is carefully inserted into the anterior vaginal fornix.
2. The inside hand is clenched into a fist while the other hand is placed on the patient's lower abdomen over the uterine fundus.
3. The uterus is compressed and massaged between the two hands until it contracts.
questions.hint: This patient meets the criteria for postpartum hemorrhage (PPH), which is defined as blood loss > 1000 mL or bleeding associated with symptoms of hypovolemia within 24 hours of delivery. The presence of an enlarged, soft uterus on examination suggests that uterine atony is the source of the patient's bleeding.

questions.text: Thirty minutes after vaginal delivery of a 2780-g (6-lb 2-oz) newborn at term, a 25-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 1, has heavy vaginal bleeding. Her pregnancy was complicated by pre-eclampsia. Her pulse is 111/min and blood pressure is 95/65 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a fundal height 2 inches below the xiphoid process of the sternum. A drug with which of the following mechanisms of action is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Depolarization of the motor end plate

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Inhibition of norepinephrine reuptake, which occurs with administration of SNRIs, tricyclic antidepressants, bupropion, amphetamine, and cocaine, can lead to vasoconstriction. Although a vasoconstrictive effect would be helpful in this patient to counteract her hypotension, norepinephrine does not have significant uterotonic effects. It would, therefore, be of limited benefit in this patient, as it fails to resolve the underlying problem, which is uterine atony.

B) CORRECT:

Oxytocin, which binds to a Gq protein-coupled receptor on uterine smooth muscle, is the first-line drug for treating PPH due to uterine atony. Activation of the oxytocin receptors activates phospholipase C, which cleaves membrane phospholipids into IP3 and DAG. IP3 binds to ion channels of the endoplasmic reticulum, releasing calcium from the endoplasmic reticulum into the cytosol. Calcium bind to calmodulin and activates myosin light chain kinase, which causes the contraction of smooth muscle. In the uterus, the blood vessels are arranged between interlacing muscle fibers. Contraction of these fibers would constrict the blood vessel and effectively decrease uterine bleeding.
Image Description:

Phospholipase C is a membrane protein that can be activated by the Gq protein or tyrosine kinases. In the activated state, phospholipase C hydrolyzes fatty acids from phospholipid PIP2, a minor component of the cell membrane. This cleavage forms two second-messenger components: IP3 (inositol triphosphate) from the head group of the phospholipid, which occurs as a solute in the cytosol, and DAG (diacylglycerol), which remains anchored to the cell membrane. Since the activation of phospholipase C by a Gq can result in numerous IP3 and DAG molecules, this step is referred to as signal gain. DAG activates protein kinase C, while IP3 binds to IP3 receptors on the membrane of the endoplasmic reticulum (ER), which stimulates an influx of calcium ions into the cytosol.

C) INCORRECT:

Depolarization of the motor end plate occurs in response to the binding of acetylcholine released from motor neurons or binding of depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agents (e.g, succinylcholine). However, the muscular layer of the uterus is not composed of skeletal muscle, but smooth muscle, which does not have a motor end plate.

D) INCORRECT:

Increased synthesis of cAMP occurs in response to Gs-protein stimulation. This cellular pathway is activated by β-agonists such as terbutaline and fenoterol, which are used for tocolysis for preterm contractions. This patient has already delivered her baby safely but is now sustaining substantial blood loss due to uterine atony. Administering β-agonists would promote uterine relaxation, which would aggravate her symptoms.

E) INCORRECT:

Analogs of prostaglandin E2 (e.g., dinoprostone) and prostaglandin F2α (e.g., carboprost) increase uterine tone and can be used as adjuncts in the treatment of postpartum hemorrhage. However, binding to prostaglandin I2 (prostacyclin) receptors leads to vasodilation and decreased platelet aggregation, which are undesirable in this bleeding patient. PGI2 analogs such as epoprostenol and iloprost are typically used to treat pulmonary arterial hypertension.
questions.hint: This patient's development of tachycardia and hypotension in combination with a uterus that has not contracted shortly after childbirth is highly indicative of postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) due to uterine atony.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman, gravida 4, para 3, at 35 weeks' gestation is admitted to the hospital in active labor. Her three children were delivered by Cesarean section. One hour after vaginal delivery, the placenta is not delivered. Manual separation of the placenta leads to profuse vaginal bleeding. Her pulse is 122/min and blood pressure is 90/67 mm Hg. A firm, nontender uterine fundus is palpated at the level of the umbilicus. Hemoglobin is 8.3 g/dL and platelet count is 220,000/mm3. Activated partial thromboplastin time and prothrombin time are within normal limits. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism of this patient's postpartum bleeding?

choices.text: Defective decidual layer of the placenta

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Uterine atony is the most common cause of postpartum hemorrhage and occurs when the uterus fails to fully contract and compress the uteroplacental vasculature after placental delivery. Patients with a history of multiple pregnancies are at increased risk. However, patients would present with a soft, enlarged and ascending uterus. This patient has a firm uterus and developed bleeding following attempted manual separation of the placenta.

B) INCORRECT:

Consumption of intravascular clotting factors occurs during DIC. While this patient's postpartum hemorrhage is a risk factor for DIC, normal values for platelet count, PT, and PTT make this an unlikely cause of her continued bleeding. Other risk factors for DIC in pregnancy include placental abruption, preeclampsia, eclampsia, HELLP, acute fatty liver of pregnancy, amniotic fluid embolism, and sepsis.

C) INCORRECT:

Patients with a history of previous C-sections are particularly prone to uterine rupture due to scarring. Uterine rupture is characterized by sudden onset vaginal bleeding during labor, associated with severe abdominal pain, uterine tenderness, maternal hemodynamic instability, and fetal distress, none of which are present here. This patient developed bleeding one hour after vaginal delivery following attempted manual separation of the placenta.

D) INCORRECT:

Vasa previa causes antepartum, not postpartum hemorrhage. This condition usually presents with a sudden onset of painless bleeding in the third trimester.

E) CORRECT:

Placenta accreta occurs when the placenta is directly adherent to the myometrium instead of the decidua basalis but does not invade or penetrate the myometrium (i.e., placenta increta). Although the exact etiology is unknown, previous C-sections are the most important risk factor. Clinically, patients present with delayed placental detachment and massive, life-threatening postpartum hemorrhage at the time of attempted manual separation of the placenta, as seen in this patient.

If placenta accreta is first diagnosed after vaginal delivery, as in this patient, emergency laparotomy is indicated to control the bleeding.
Image Description:

Placental attachment disorders are classified according to the depth of implantation of the trophoblast in the uterine wall:

– Left: Normal placentation
– Placenta accreta: chorionic villi attach to the myometrium rather than the decidua basalis (but do not invade or penetrate the myometrium)
– Placenta increta: chorionic villi invade or penetrate into the myometrium
– Placenta percreta: chorionic villi penetrate the myometrium, penetrate the serosa, and, in some cases, adjacent organs/structures
questions.hint: Prior C-sections are an important risk factor for this condition.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 1, develops progressive weakness and sweating 30 minutes after giving birth to a healthy, 4250-g (9-lb 6-oz) newborn. The child was born via vaginal delivery after induction of labor at 39 weeks' gestation following a pregnancy complicated by gestational diabetes mellitus. Placental expulsion occurred 15 minutes after delivery of the child and showed a normal-sized placenta with medial umbilical cord insertion and complete amniotic membranes. Postpartum blood loss is estimated to be 1000 mL. The patient appears pale and exhausted. Her temperature is 37.4°C (99.3°F), pulse is 111/min, and blood pressure is 85/60 mm Hg. Abdominal examination shows a firm, mildly tender uterus with the uterine fundus palpable at the level of the maternal umbilicus. External genital examination shows an intact vulva and perineum. There is persistent vaginal bleeding. A complete blood count shows a hemoglobin concentration of 10 g/dL compared to 11.5 g/dL on admission; prothrombin time is 15 seconds, and partial thromboplastin time is 36 seconds. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's clinical findings?

choices.text: Retention of placental tissue in the uterus

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Rupture of the uterine wall is a rare but life-threatening cause of PPH. Patients with uterine rupture present with severe abdominal pain and severe uterine tenderness on abdominal examination, none of which is seen here. Moreover, this condition is more common in women with a history of previous cesarean delivery or multiple uterine surgeries.

B) INCORRECT:

Uterine atony is responsible for 80% of cases of PPH. Fetal macrosomia, which is seen here, is also a known risk factor for uterine atony. However, uterine atony manifests with a soft, enlarged, and boggy uterus, whereas this patient's examination shows a firm uterus with the uterine fundus palpable at the level of the umbilicus.

C) INCORRECT:

Retained placenta is a known cause of PPH. While women with retained placenta present with delayed (> 30 minutes) or improper separation of the placenta, this patient's placental expulsion occurred 15 minutes after delivery and was complete. Inspection of the expulsed placental tissue showed a normal-sized placenta and complete amniotic membranes.

D) CORRECT:

Genital tract injury is the second most common cause of PPH. Patients with cervical or vaginal lacerations present with a well-contracted uterus and active vaginal bleeding without visible injuries of the vulva or perineum. Causes for genital tract lacerations include fetal macrosomia, fetal malpresentation, and iatrogenic injury (e.g., operative vaginal delivery, episiotomy). Women with suspected genital birth trauma should undergo immediate genital tract inspection and repair of any visible bleeding laceration.

E) INCORRECT:

Postpartum blood loss of 1000 mL following vaginal delivery associated with features of hypovolemia (hypotension, tachycardia), as seen in this patient, indicates PPH rather than normal postpartum blood loss.
questions.hint: Features of hypovolemia (hypotension, tachycardia) following vaginal delivery in a patient with an estimated postpartum blood loss of 1000 mL are consistent with postpartum hemorrhage (PPH).

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman, gravida 4, para 3, at 38 weeks' gestation is admitted to the hospital in active labor. She reports that her “water broke” yesterday, and she has had malodorous discharge since then. Her pregnancy was complicated by polyhydramnios. On admission, she has regular contractions that occur every 2 minutes, and her cervix is 10 cm dilated and fully effaced. After vaginal delivery of a 4136-g (9-lb 2-oz) male newborn, intravenous oxytocin infusion is started for active management of the third stage of labor, and the placenta is delivered completely. Shortly after, the patient develops heavy vaginal bleeding with clots. Her temperature is 37.8°C (100°F), pulse is 105/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 112/74 mm Hg. Examination shows a soft uterus that is palpated 5 cm above the umbilicus. Her bleeding continues despite bimanual uterine massage and manual removal of intrauterine clots. Administration of intravenous fluids is begun. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Transfusion of fresh frozen plasma, in combination with RBC, may be indicated in patients with suspected coagulation disorders. In patients with ongoing PPH, early transfusion of blood products should be considered. Although there is no consensus on the optimal ratio of blood products in PPH due to uterine atony, most institutions have individual massive transfusion protocols for obstetric patients, which should be implemented. This patient has a soft, enlarged uterus and is showing no signs of coagulopathy (e.g., petechiae), so uterine atony is the most likely cause of hemorrhage, not a coagulation disorder.

B) INCORRECT:

Placement of uterine compression sutures is indicated in patients with PPH due to uterine atony that is unresponsive to conservative management. A modified B-Lynch suture can preserve future fertility, thereby eliminating the need for hysterectomy. However, this patient is hemodynamically stable, so other noninvasive interventions should be considered first.

C) CORRECT:

Oxytocin induces uterine contraction and should be routinely administered to all women in the third stage of labor (active management of the third stage of labor) to reduce the risk of developing PPH. In patients with PPH and suspected uterine atony, the first-line therapy is to administer additional IV oxytocin along with bimanual uterine massage, followed by other uterotonic agents (e.g., intramuscular methylergonovine, sublingual/intracavitary misoprostol) and tranexamic acid. When initial therapies fail to stop the bleeding, bleeding disorders (e.g., disseminated intravascular coagulation, hyperfibrinolysis) should be excluded. Surgical interventions, such as placement of uterine compression sutures or hysterectomy, become necessary if conservative therapy shows no effect within 30 minutes.

Uterine atony is the most common cause of PPH. This patient's history of multiparity, polyhydramnios, and chorioamnionitis are known risk factors for uterine atony.
Image Description:

1. One hand is carefully inserted into the anterior vaginal fornix.
2. The inside hand is clenched into a fist while the other hand is placed on the patient's lower abdomen over the uterine fundus.
3. The uterus is compressed and massaged between the two hands until it contracts.

D) INCORRECT:

Administering prostaglandins, such as misoprostol or carboprost, induces smooth muscle contraction in the uterus and may be considered in PPH that is unresponsive to first-line uterotonic drugs or in scenarios where other uterotonic drugs are unavailable or contraindicated (e.g., patients with preexisting hypertension). This patient, however, has not received any uterotonic drug. Another intervention should be considered first.

E) INCORRECT:

Uterine tamponade with a balloon catheter or intrauterine pack may be indicated in PPH due to uterine atony unresponsive to conservative management. This intervention decreases bleeding and provides time to prepare for other surgical procedures, such as placement of uterine compression sutures. This patient is hemodynamically stable, so other noninvasive interventions should be considered first.

F) INCORRECT:

Administration of methylergonovine may be considered in PPH due to uterine atony that is unresponsive to high-dose first-line uterotonic drugs. Methylergonovine promotes uterine contraction and increases blood pressure, and is thus contraindicated in patients with hypertension or preeclampsia. This woman is hemodynamically stable and has only received the standard oxytocin dose for active management of the third stage of labor, making another intervention more appropriate at this time.
questions.hint: This patient has postpartum hemorrhage (PPH), as evidenced by the heavy vaginal bleeding after giving birth. Her soft, enlarged uterus indicates uterine atony as an underlying cause.

questions.text: A 34-year-old primigravid woman at 38 weeks' gestation is admitted to the hospital for induction of labor. Her pregnancy has been complicated by gestational diabetes treated with insulin during the third trimester of pregnancy. Her medical and family history are unremarkable. After receiving cervical ripening agents, intravenous administration of oxytocin is initiated. Twenty-five minutes after the delivery of a 4100-g (9-lb) female newborn, the patient reports severe lower abdominal pain and lightheadedness. The placenta has not yet been delivered. She appears somnolent. Her temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), pulse is 94/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 88/55 mm Hg. Pelvic examination shows profuse vaginal bleeding and a soft, round mass protruding from the vagina. The uterine fundus cannot be palpated. In addition to administering intravenous fluids, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Perform manual removal of the placenta
Perform manual repositioning of the uterus

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Uterotonic drugs (e.g., oxytocin) should be discontinued in all patients with uterine inversion to lessen further contraction of the lower uterine segment and cervix.

B) INCORRECT:

Manual removal of the placenta in patients with uterine inversion can increase blood loss and worsen hypotension. Another intervention is required before the placenta is removed.

C) INCORRECT:

Administration of uterine relaxants (e.g., nitroglycerin) can be considered in the management of hemodynamically stable patients with uterine inversion. However, in hemodynamically unstable patients such as this one, nitroglycerin may worsen hypotension.

D) CORRECT:

Immediate manual repositioning is indicated in all patients with uterine inversion to prevent hemorrhagic shock. Manual reduction becomes more challenging with time, as further contraction of the cervix and lower uterine segment can create a constriction ring. Uterotonic drugs should be discontinued before the procedure to relax the myometrium and facilitate repositioning. After successful repositioning, uterotonic drugs should be administered to prevent uterine atony and reinversion. If the placenta has not yet been delivered, it is usually removed after successful repositioning, because removal during uterine inversion can increase blood loss and cause or worsen hemodynamic instability.

If manual repositioning is unsuccessful laparotomy is indicated for hemodynamically unstable patients. For hemodynamically stable patients in whom repositioning has failed, uterine relaxants (e.g., nitroglycerin) can be administered and the procedure reattempted.
Image Description:

1. Grasp the protruding portion of the uterus.
2. Direct fingers towards the posterior fornix.
3. Lift the uterus into the abdominal cavity.

E) INCORRECT:

Laparotomy and surgical repair can be considered in hemodynamically unstable patients with uterine inversion, like this patient. However, a different intervention should be attempted before proceeding to surgery.
questions.hint: Severe lower abdominal pain, profuse vaginal bleeding, inability to palpate the uterine fundus and a soft, round mass protruding from the vagina shortly after delivery suggest acute uterine inversion. Risk factors for this condition include fetal macrosomia, nulliparity, excessive traction on the umbilical cord, and excessive external fundal pressure.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old gravida 3, para 3 woman experiences persistent postpartum hemorrhage 20 minutes after precipitous spontaneous vaginal delivery of a healthy infant at 39 weeks, 2 days' gestation. Her pregnancy was uncomplicated. A small amount of lochia immediately after delivery slowed down after uterine massage. The placenta was delivered with gentle traction one minute after delivery of the infant. There were no trailing membranes, and the placenta appeared to be intact. There was no episiotomy and no visible vaginal or perineal lacerations.
Since the bleeding began, the patient has received intravenous oxytocin, rectal misoprostol, and an intramuscular dose of methylergonovine. Her bleeding continues, and the total estimated loss is at 1100 mL.
The uterus continues to feel firm and small.
What is the most likely cause of this patient’s postpartum hemorrhage?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Postpartum hemorrhage has traditionally been defined as a loss of >500 mL of blood after vaginal delivery or >1000 mL after cesarean birth. More recently, an updated definition has been implemented that applies regardless of route of delivery. Currently, postpartum hemorrhage is defined as cumulative blood loss ≥1000 mL or blood loss accompanied by signs or symptoms of hypovolemia within 24 hours after the birth process.

Risk factors for postpartum hemorrhage include a prolonged third stage of labor, multiple gestations, episiotomy, fetal macrosomia, and a history of postpartum hemorrhage. However, postpartum hemorrhage can occur in women with no risk factors. Examination usually uncovers the cause, using “the four Ts” mnemonic guide: tone, tissue, thrombin, and trauma.

Uterine atony, the most common cause of postpartum hemorrhage, can be detected and often corrected by bimanual examination and massage of the uterus. Uterotonic medications (such as oxytocin, misoprostol, methylergonovine, and carboprost) can also be used, as in this case. However, if the uterus is firm to palpation, another source of bleeding should be sought.

A laceration of the vagina or cervix is the second most common cause of postpartum hemorrhage. Although no perineal or vaginal lacerations were seen in this case, the entire birth canal from perineum to cervix should be inspected when there is no other obvious source of bleeding. Risk factors for cervical laceration include precipitous labor, operative vaginal delivery, and previous cerclage. The adequate lighting and exposure of an operating room are often necessary for cervical repairs.

Key learning point: In a woman who has a small, firm uterus by palpation, the most likely cause of persistent postpartum hemorrhage that has not responded to appropriate uterotonic medications is an occult cervical laceration.

B) INCORRECT:

Retained placenta, in part or whole, prevents the uterus from contracting to slow bleeding. Careful examination of the placenta for missing components or lobes, and examination of the vagina for trailing membranes, can often disclose this cause. In this case, the placenta was delivered completely intact.

C) INCORRECT:

Uterine rupture is rare and is typically seen only after previous uterine surgery. Induction or augmentation of a uterus that was previously scarred (often from a previous cesarean section) increases the risk for rupture.

D) INCORRECT:

Coagulation disorders, such as disseminated intravascular coagulation, are a rare cause of postpartum hemorrhage but can be life-threatening. Immune thrombocytopenia, thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura, von Willebrand disease, hemophilia, and HELLP syndrome are all possible causes of hemorrhage. Coagulation defects are rare but should be suspected in patients who have not responded to the usual measures to treat postpartum hemorrhage.

E) INCORRECT:

Uterine atony, the most common cause of postpartum hemorrhage, can be detected and often corrected by bimanual examination and massage of the uterus. Uterotonic medications (such as oxytocin, misoprostol, methylergonovine, and carboprost) can also be used, as in this case. However, if the uterus is firm to palpation, another source of bleeding should be sought.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old gravida 3, para 3 woman who delivered vaginally 3 days ago presents with a one-day history of heavy vaginal bleeding. She is soaking a pad every 3 hours with bright-red blood. She reports some cramping but no malodorous discharge. Her pregnancy, labor, and delivery were uncomplicated, and she had no perineal lacerations. She has no history of excessive bleeding.
Her blood pressure is 120/70 mm Hg, her heart rate is 80 beats per minute, and her temperature is 37°C. Her fundus is firm, nontender, and at the umbilicus. There is red blood emanating from the cervical os, but no other bleeding source is seen.
In addition to medical stabilization, what is the most appropriate next step in this patient's care?

choices.text: Order an ultrasound of the uterus

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oxytocin and misoprostol are uterotonic drugs that are not indicated in a patient who has a firm uterus.

B) INCORRECT:

Dilation and curettage is not indicated in a stable patient with an uncertain diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Oxytocin and misoprostol are uterotonic drugs that are not indicated in a patient who has a firm uterus.

D) INCORRECT:

Desmopressin exerts a hemostatic effect by inducing the release of von Willebrand factor and can be useful to treat bleeding episodes in patients with platelet-function defects. Secondary postpartum hemorrhage is not an indication for treatment with desmopressin.

E) CORRECT:

Secondary postpartum hemorrhage is defined as any abnormal or excessive vaginal bleeding that occurs 24 hours to 12 weeks after delivery. Although it is not usually catastrophic, secondary postpartum hemorrhage can be associated with significant morbidity; in a study of 132 consecutive cases, 84% of women required hospital admission, 63% required surgical evacuation, and 17% required blood transfusion.

Approximately 0.5% to 2.0% of postpartum women experience secondary postpartum hemorrhage. The most common causes are uterine atony, coagulopathy, perineal lacerations, infection, and retained placental products.

For this particular patient — who has a firm fundus, no signs of infection, no lacerations, and no known history of a bleeding disorder — the most likely cause of the hemorrhage is retained placental products. An ultrasound with color Doppler can help document the presence of such products.

Women with secondary postpartum hemorrhage should be admitted to the hospital if they show any signs of hemodynamic instability.

Key learning point: The most likely cause of secondary postpartum hemorrhage in a patient who has a firm fundus, no signs of infection, and no lacerations is retained placental products.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old primigravida woman delivers a healthy infant vaginally at 38 weeks’ gestation after an uncomplicated routine prenatal course and uncomplicated first and second stages of labor.
Thirty minutes after delivery of the infant, the placenta has not been expelled despite gentle traction on the umbilical cord and administration of intramuscular oxytocin. Repeat traction on the umbilical cord 60 minutes after delivery of the infant is unsuccessful in removing the placenta. The patient's blood pressure is 120/72 mm Hg, and her heart rate is 80 beats per minute. The placenta cannot be visualized on genitourinary inspection.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Infuse oxytocin into the umbilical vein
Manage expectantly with close observation but not medications for another 30 minutes
Give a second dose of oxytocin, and prepare for manual extraction of the placenta

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Infusion of oxytocin into the umbilical vein is not superior to expectant management for treatment of retained placenta.

B) INCORRECT:

A placenta that is not expelled within 30 minutes after infant delivery is considered to be “retained,” and alternative means of delivery should be considered. Active management of the third stage of labor — including uterine massage, gentle cord traction, and early administration of intramuscular or intravenous oxytocin — can be helpful in the setting of a retained placenta and is preferred over continued expectant management.

C) CORRECT:

A placenta that is not expelled within 30 minutes after infant delivery is considered to be “retained,” and alternative means of delivery should be considered. Placental retention is associated with an increased risk for postpartum hemorrhage.

Active management of the third stage of labor — including uterine massage, gentle cord traction, and early administration of intramuscular or intravenous oxytocin — can be helpful in the setting of a retained placenta and is preferred over continued expectant management. Oxytocin can be given in repeated doses if needed, but if the placenta is not delivered after one or two doses of oxytocin, or if there is excessive vaginal bleeding, then manual extraction of the placenta should be attempted. In addition, some clinicians may consider administration of sublingual nitroglycerine to relax the smooth muscle of the uterus and assist with placental delivery, although the evidence for this approach is mixed, and it has been associated with higher rates of bleeding.

Key learning point: The most appropriate management of a persistently retained placenta after one dose of oxytocin and gentle traction on the umbilical cord is administration of a second dose of oxytocin and an attempt at manual extraction of the placenta.

D) INCORRECT:

Ergotamine is an ergot alkaloid, uterotonic drug that causes contraction of the lower uterine segment. It is not indicated late in the third stage of labor because contraction of the lower uterine segment might inhibit placental passage.

E) INCORRECT:

There is no evidence that tocolytics, such as magnesium sulfate, lead to placental delivery or reduce the need for manual extraction.

questions.text:
A 22-year-old gravida 2, para 2 woman develops persistent vaginal bleeding immediately after the vaginal delivery of her child, which involved a 30-hour induction requiring continuous infusion of oxytocin. The pregnancy was uncomplicated, and the patient takes no medications except for an albuterol inhaler for asthma.
After the patient delivers the placenta (intact), the volume of blood loss exceeds 1050 mL. The uterus is boggy despite aggressive uterine massage, intramuscular injection of oxytocin, and an ongoing oxytocin infusion. No cervical laceration is evident on examination, and no clots are present in the lower uterine segment.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Provide an additional dose of oxytocin intravenously

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Nitroglycerine is a uterine relaxant and is not indicated in the setting of postpartum hemorrhage.

B) INCORRECT:

Terbutaline is a uterine relaxant and is not indicated in the setting of postpartum hemorrhage.

C) INCORRECT:

Carboprost is contraindicated in women with asthma because it is a potent bronchoconstrictor.

D) INCORRECT:

Oxytocin is used as an intravenous push for postpartum hemorrhage in some international settings, but this approach is controversial because it can lead to maternal hypotension.

E) CORRECT:

Postpartum hemorrhage (defined as cumulative blood loss ≥1000 mL or blood loss accompanied by sights or symptoms of hypovolemia within 24 hours after the birth process) is the most common cause of maternal morbidity in developed countries and a major cause of death worldwide.

Intramuscular methylergonovine, an ergot alkaloid with uterotonic properties, is an appropriate agent for postpartum hemorrhage. When this medication is dosed at 0.2 mg intramuscularly, the onset of action is fewer than 5 minutes. Caution should be exercised in patients with high blood pressure. Methylergonovine is not administered intravenously because of the risk for sudden hypertensive or cerebrovascular events.

Carboprost is an alternative drug for management of postpartum hemorrhage. It is contraindicated in women with asthma because it is a potent bronchoconstrictor.

Other agents are occasionally used in select cases. For example, misoprostol and tranexamic acid are not approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration for postpartum hemorrhage but are sometimes used for this indication.

Key learning point: Women with postpartum hemorrhage who have a history of asthma should avoid the medication carboprost.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 42 weeks' gestation is admitted to the hospital in active labor. Her first child was delivered by lower segment transverse cesarean section because of a nonreassuring fetal heart rate. She undergoes an elective repeat lower segment transverse cesarean section with complete removal of the placenta. Shortly after the operation, she starts having heavy uterine bleeding with passage of clots. Examination shows a soft uterus on palpation. Her bleeding continues despite fundal massage and the use of packing, oxytocin, misoprostol, and carboprost. Her pulse rate is now 120/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 90/70 mm Hg. Her hemoglobin is 8 g/dL. Mass transfusion protocol is activated and a B-Lynch uterine compression suture is placed to control her bleeding. Which of the following is the most likely cause of her postpartum complication?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Uterine atony usually manifests with an enlarged, soft, non-contracted uterus and significant vaginal bleeding after delivery due to insufficient myometrial blood vessel constriction. In uterine atony, bimanual uterine massage and uterotonic agents (oxytocin, misoprostol, carboprost) should be used to promote uterine contraction and tranexamic acid may be indicated to stop fibrinolysis. If the uterus remains soft and bleeding persists, a B-Lynch uterine compression suture can be placed to control bleeding. PPH is an emergency, as it is the number one cause of maternal mortality worldwide.

B) INCORRECT:

Uterine inversion is a rare cause of postpartum hemorrhage and usually occurs in vaginal delivery involving an attached placenta. On vaginal examination, the endometrium is visible as a red bulging mass.

C) INCORRECT:

Although PPH may rarely be the first manifestation of placenta accreta, this condition is associated with the delivery of an incomplete placenta, unlike the placenta in this patient. Placenta accreta is usually diagnosed prior to delivery on ultrasound.

D) INCORRECT:

Hemorrhage can occur from tearing along the lateral aspect of the initial uterine incision, either spontaneously or during delivery of the fetus. However, this type of hemorrhage is usually detected before closing the abdomen. Furthermore, in this case, the uterus would be contracted and firm.

E) INCORRECT:

Uterine rupture can cause postpartum hemorrhage. However, this condition more commonly occurs intrapartum in women with a prior vertical (not transverse) hysterotomy who attempt a vaginal delivery. This patient's soft, enlarged uterus post-cesarean section suggests a most more common etiology of postpartum hemorrhage.
questions.hint: This complication is the most common cause of postpartum hemorrhage (PPH). Overdistention of the uterus (e.g., multiparity, post-term pregnancy) is a risk factor for this condition.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 2, delivers twins via an uncomplicated vaginal delivery. The patient received regular prenatal care. Pregnancy was uncomplicated. Shortly after complete delivery of both placentas, there is profuse vaginal bleeding. Postpartum blood loss is estimated to be 1150 mL. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows an enlarged, soft uterus. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Uterine artery embolization can be used as a fertility-sparing procedure in patients with slow, hemodynamically stable, yet persistent PPH. Uterine artery embolization is an appropriate treatment option in patients that do not respond to conservative management; however, this patient should first undergo a different intervention.

B) INCORRECT:

Prostaglandins such as misoprostol and carboprost are uterotonic agents that can be used as second-line agents in the management of uterine atony. These drugs have potentially severe side effects (e.g., hypertension, fever, bronchospasm) and should therefore only be used after other interventions have failed to adequately control the bleeding.

C) INCORRECT:

Curettage with suctioning is a treatment modality that can be used for PPH secondary to retained placental tissue. Risk factors for placental retention include prior uterine surgery, uterine fibroids, and preterm delivery. This patient's presentation is consistent with uterine atony, which is not treated by curettage with suctioning.

D) INCORRECT:

Tranexamic acid is an antifibrinolytic agent that acts to prevent plasmin-mediated breakdown of fibrin and can be used to treat excessive bleeding. Although tranexamic acid has been shown to reduce mortality and blood loss from obstetric hemorrhage, it is not the intervention of choice. However, it should be administered immediately if initial interventions fail to adequately control bleeding since delayed administration can decrease its efficacy.

E) CORRECT:

Uterine atony is the most common cause of PPH, accounting for 70–80% of all cases. Initial management involves bimanual uterine massage to induce uterine contraction and the constriction of blood vessels. In addition, patients should receive intravenous fluid resuscitation with crystalloid fluids and an increase in oxytocin infusion to induce uterine contractions. Oxytocin should be routinely administered to all women in the third stage of labor to reduce the risk of developing PPH.

Risk factors for uterine atony include multiparity leading to uterine overdistention (as seen in this patient), prolonged labor, induction of labor, and chorioamnionitis.
Image Description:

1. One hand is carefully inserted into the anterior vaginal fornix.
2. The inside hand is clenched into a fist while the other hand is placed on the patient's lower abdomen over the uterine fundus.
3. The uterus is compressed and massaged between the two hands until it contracts.
questions.hint: This patient meets the criteria for postpartum hemorrhage (PPH), which is defined as blood loss > 1000 mL or bleeding associated with symptoms of hypovolemia within 24 hours of delivery. The presence of an enlarged, soft uterus on examination suggests that uterine atony is the source of the patient's bleeding.

However, if the uterus is firm to palpation, another source of bleeding should be sought.

A laceration of the vagina or cervix is the second most common cause of postpartum hemorrhage. Although no perineal or vaginal lacerations were seen in this case, the entire birth canal from perineum to cervix should be inspected when there is no other obvious source of bleeding. Risk factors for cervical laceration include precipitous labor, operative vaginal delivery, and previous cerclage.
